title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text: pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text: exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.1 data

ggplot(data=exam_data)














Note




A blank canvas appears.
ggplot() initializes a ggplot object.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.2 Aesthetic Mappings

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))














Note




X-axis is included here.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.3 geom

geom_bar()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) + 
  geom_bar()










geom_dotplot()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)














Warning




Misleading y-scale.




ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)  














Note




scale_y_continuous() is used to turn off the y-axis.





geom_histogram()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram()










Modifying geom object

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue") 









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")










geom_density()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()










geom_boxplot()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)














Note




Notch is used to help visually assess whether the medians of distributions differ.





geom_violin()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()










geom_point()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() 










Combining geom objects

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.4 stat

stat_summary()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)   










geom_point()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun="mean",           
             colour="red",          
             size=4)  










geom_smooth()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.5 Facets

facet_wrap()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)










facet_grid()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.6 Coordinates

Flipping axis

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()










Changing axis range

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
3.7 Themes

GrayClassicMinimal



ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()











ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()











ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 fundamentals
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 fundamentals
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 fundamentals
text: exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 fundamentals
text:
4.1 Single graph

p1p2p3



p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

p1











p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")

p2











p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

p3

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 fundamentals
text:
4.2 Composite graphs: patchwork

Two-Column Layout using the Plus Sign +.
Parenthesis () to create a subplot group.
Two-Row Layout using the Division Sign /


Combining 2 graphs

p1 + p2










Combining 3 graphs

(p1 / p2) | p3










Creating composite fig with tag

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')










Creating fig with insert

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)










Creating composite fig with patchwork & ggtheme

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
pacman::p_load(ggiraph, plotly, 
               patchwork, DT, tidyverse) 





exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
pacman::p_load(ggiraph, plotly, 
               patchwork, DT, tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text: exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.1 Tooltip effect with tooltip aesthetic
First, an ggplot object will be created. Next, girafe() of ggiraph will be used to create an interactive svg object.


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = ID),
    stackgroups = TRUE, 
    binwidth = 1, 
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, 
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 6,
  height_svg = 6*0.618
)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.2 Displaying multiple information on tooltip
The first three lines of codes in the code chunk create a new field called tooltip. At the same time, it populates text in ID and CLASS fields into the newly created field.


Code
exam_data$tooltip <- c(paste0(     
  "Name = ", exam_data$ID,         
  "\n Class = ", exam_data$CLASS)) 

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = exam_data$tooltip), 
    stackgroups = TRUE,
    binwidth = 1,
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 8,
  height_svg = 8*0.618
)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.3 Customizing tooltip style


Code
tooltip_css <- "background-color:black; #<<
font-style:bold; color:white;" #<<

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(tooltip = ID),                   
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(    #<<
    opts_tooltip(    #<<
      css = tooltip_css)) #<<
)












Note




The background color of the tooltip is black and the font is black and bold.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.4 Displaying statistics on tooltip


Code
tooltip <- function(y, ymax, accuracy = .01) {
  mean <- scales::number(y, accuracy = accuracy)
  sem <- scales::number(ymax - y, accuracy = accuracy)
  paste("Mean maths scores:", mean, "+/-", sem)
}

gg_point <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
                   aes(x = RACE),
) +
  stat_summary(aes(y = MATHS, 
                   tooltip = after_stat(  
                     tooltip(y, ymax))),  
    fun.data = "mean_se", 
    geom = GeomInteractiveCol,  
    fill = "light blue"
  ) +
  stat_summary(aes(y = MATHS),
    fun.data = mean_se,
    geom = "errorbar", width = 0.2, size = 0.2
  )

girafe(ggobj = gg_point,
       width_svg = 8,
       height_svg = 8*0.618)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.5 Hover effect with data_id aesthetic


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(           
    aes(data_id = CLASS),             
    stackgroups = TRUE,               
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618                      
)                 












Note




The default value of the hover css is hover_css = “fill:orange;”

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.6 Styling hover effect


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = CLASS),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(                        
    opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),  
    opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;") 
  )                                        
)            












Note




The ccs customisation request are encoded directly.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.7 Combining tooltip and hover effect


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(tooltip = CLASS, 
        data_id = CLASS),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(                        
    opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),  
    opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;") 
  )                                        
)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.8 Click effect with onclick
onclick argument of ggiraph provides hotlink interactivity on the web.


Code
exam_data$onclick <- sprintf("window.open(\"%s%s\")",
"https://www.moe.gov.sg/schoolfinder?journey=Primary%20school",
as.character(exam_data$ID))

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(onclick = onclick),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618)












Warning



Note that click actions must be a string column in the dataset containing valid javascript instructions.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.8 Coordinated Multiple Views with ggiraph

Appropriate interactive functions of ggiraph will be used to create the multiple views.
patchwork function of patchwork package will be used inside girafe function to create the interactive coordinated multiple views.



Code
p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = ID),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = ID),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

girafe(code = print(p1 + p2), 
       width_svg = 6,
       height_svg = 3,
       options = list(
         opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),
         opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;")
         )
       )

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
section: 3.1 Creating an interactive scatter plot: plot_ly()
text:
3.1 Creating an interactive scatter plot: plot_ly()

plot_ly(data = exam_data, 
             x = ~MATHS, 
             y = ~ENGLISH)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
3.2 Working with visual variable: plot_ly()

plot_ly(data = exam_data, 
        x = ~ENGLISH, 
        y = ~MATHS, 
        color = ~RACE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
section: 3.3 Creating an interactive scatter plot: ggplotly()
text:
3.3 Creating an interactive scatter plot: ggplotly()

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
            aes(x = MATHS,
                y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))
ggplotly(p)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
3.4 Coordinated Multiple Views with plotly

highlight_key() of plotly package is used as shared data.
Two scatterplots will be created by using ggplot2 functions.
Lastly, subplot() of plotly package is used to place them next to each other side-by-side.



Code
d <- highlight_key(exam_data)
p1 <- ggplot(data=d, 
            aes(x = MATHS,
                y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

p2 <- ggplot(data=d, 
            aes(x = MATHS,
                y = SCIENCE)) +
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))
subplot(ggplotly(p1),
        ggplotly(p2))

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
4.1 Interactive Data Table: DT package

DT::datatable(exam_data, class= "compact")

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
4.2 Linked brushing: crosstalk


Code
d <- highlight_key(exam_data) 
p <- ggplot(d, 
            aes(ENGLISH, 
                MATHS)) + 
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

gg <- highlight(ggplotly(p),        
                "plotly_selected")  

crosstalk::bscols(gg,               
                  DT::datatable(d), 
                  widths = 5)      






















Note




highlight() is a function of plotly package. It sets a variety of options for brushing (i.e., highlighting) multiple plots. These options are primarily designed for linking multiple plotly graphs, and may not behave as expected when linking plotly to another htmlwidget package via crosstalk. In some cases, other htmlwidgets will respect these options, such as persistent selection in leaflet.
bscols() is a helper function of crosstalk package. It makes it easy to put HTML elements side by side. It can be called directly from the console but is especially designed to work in an R Markdown document. Warning: This will bring in all of Bootstrap!.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
text:
pacman::p_load(readxl, gifski, gapminder,
               plotly, gganimate, tidyverse)




mutate_each_() is used to convert all character data type into factor. across() can also be used to derive the same outputs.

12



col <- c("Country", "Continent")
globalPop <- read_xls("../data/GlobalPopulation.xls",
                      sheet="Data") %>%
  mutate_at(col, as.factor) %>%
  mutate(Year = as.integer(Year))




col <- c("Country", "Continent")
globalPop <- read_xls("../data/GlobalPopulation.xls",
                      sheet="Data") %>%
  mutate(across(col, as.factor)) %>%
  mutate(Year = as.integer(Year))

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
text:
pacman::p_load(readxl, gifski, gapminder,
               plotly, gganimate, tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
text:
mutate_each_() is used to convert all character data type into factor. across() can also be used to derive the same outputs.

12



col <- c("Country", "Continent")
globalPop <- read_xls("../data/GlobalPopulation.xls",
                      sheet="Data") %>%
  mutate_at(col, as.factor) %>%
  mutate(Year = as.integer(Year))




col <- c("Country", "Continent")
globalPop <- read_xls("../data/GlobalPopulation.xls",
                      sheet="Data") %>%
  mutate(across(col, as.factor)) %>%
  mutate(Year = as.integer(Year))

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
section: 2.1 Building a static population bubble plot
text:
2.1 Building a static population bubble plot

ggplot(globalPop, aes(x = Old, y = Young, 
                      size = Population, 
                      colour = Country)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7, 
             show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_colour_manual(values = country_colors) +
  scale_size(range = c(2, 12)) +
  labs(title = 'Year: {frame_time}', 
       x = '% Aged', 
       y = '% Young')

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
text:
2.2 Building the animated bubble plot

transition_time() of gganimate is used to create transition through distinct states in time (i.e. Year).
ease_aes() is used to control easing of aesthetics. The default is linear. Other methods are: quadratic, cubic, quartic, quintic, sine, circular, exponential, elastic, back, and bounce.


ggplot(globalPop, aes(x = Old, y = Young, 
                      size = Population, 
                      colour = Country)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7, 
             show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_colour_manual(values = country_colors) +
  scale_size(range = c(2, 12)) +
  labs(title = 'Year: {frame_time}', 
       x = '% Aged', 
       y = '% Young') +
  transition_time(Year) +       
  ease_aes('linear')

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
section: 3.1 Building an animated bubble plot: ggplotly()
text:
3.1 Building an animated bubble plot: ggplotly()

Important




Error Warning: Ignoring unknown aesthetics: frame occurred.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Animated Statistical Graphics with R
section: 3.2 Building an animated bubble plot: plot_ly()
text:
3.2 Building an animated bubble plot: plot_ly()

bp <- globalPop %>%
  plot_ly(x = ~Old, 
          y = ~Young, 
          size = ~Population, 
          color = ~Continent,
          sizes = c(2, 100),
          frame = ~Year, 
          text = ~Country, 
          hoverinfo = "text",
          type = 'scatter',
          mode = 'markers'
          ) %>%
  layout(showlegend = FALSE)
bp

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.1 Tooltip effect with tooltip aesthetic
First, an ggplot object will be created. Next, girafe() of ggiraph will be used to create an interactive svg object.


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = ID),
    stackgroups = TRUE, 
    binwidth = 1, 
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, 
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 6,
  height_svg = 6*0.618
)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.2 Displaying multiple information on tooltip
The first three lines of codes in the code chunk create a new field called tooltip. At the same time, it populates text in ID and CLASS fields into the newly created field.


Code
exam_data$tooltip <- c(paste0(     
  "Name = ", exam_data$ID,         
  "\n Class = ", exam_data$CLASS)) 

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = exam_data$tooltip), 
    stackgroups = TRUE,
    binwidth = 1,
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

  ggobj = p,

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.3 Customizing tooltip style


Code
tooltip_css <- "background-color:black; #<<
font-style:bold; color:white;" #<<

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(tooltip = ID),                   
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(    #<<
    opts_tooltip(    #<<
      css = tooltip_css)) #<<
)












Note




The background color of the tooltip is black and the font is black and bold.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.4 Displaying statistics on tooltip


Code
tooltip <- function(y, ymax, accuracy = .01) {
  mean <- scales::number(y, accuracy = accuracy)
  sem <- scales::number(ymax - y, accuracy = accuracy)
  paste("Mean maths scores:", mean, "+/-", sem)
}

gg_point <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
                   aes(x = RACE),
) +
  stat_summary(aes(y = MATHS, 
                   tooltip = after_stat(  
                     tooltip(y, ymax))),  
    fun.data = "mean_se", 
    geom = GeomInteractiveCol,  
    fill = "light blue"
  ) +
  stat_summary(aes(y = MATHS),
    fun.data = mean_se,
    geom = "errorbar", width = 0.2, size = 0.2
  )

girafe(ggobj = gg_point,
       width_svg = 8,
       height_svg = 8*0.618)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.5 Hover effect with data_id aesthetic


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(           
    aes(data_id = CLASS),             
    stackgroups = TRUE,               
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618                      
)                 












Note




The default value of the hover css is hover_css = “fill:orange;”

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.6 Styling hover effect


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = CLASS),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(                        
    opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),  
    opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;") 
  )                                        
)            












Note




The ccs customisation request are encoded directly.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.7 Combining tooltip and hover effect


Code
p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(tooltip = CLASS, 
        data_id = CLASS),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(                        
    opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),  
    opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;") 
  )                                        
)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.8 Click effect with onclick
onclick argument of ggiraph provides hotlink interactivity on the web.


Code
exam_data$onclick <- sprintf("window.open(\"%s%s\")",
"https://www.moe.gov.sg/schoolfinder?journey=Primary%20school",
as.character(exam_data$ID))

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(onclick = onclick),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618)












Warning



Note that click actions must be a string column in the dataset containing valid javascript instructions.

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
2.8 Coordinated Multiple Views with ggiraph

Appropriate interactive functions of ggiraph will be used to create the multiple views.
patchwork function of patchwork package will be used inside girafe function to create the interactive coordinated multiple views.



Code
p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = ID),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = ID),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

girafe(code = print(p1 + p2), 
       width_svg = 6,
       height_svg = 3,
       options = list(
         opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),
         opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;")
         )
       )

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R

plot_ly(data = exam_data, 
             x = ~MATHS, 
             y = ~ENGLISH)

plot_ly(data = exam_data, 
        x = ~ENGLISH, 
        y = ~MATHS, 
        color = ~RACE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
section: 3.3 Creating an interactive scatter plot: ggplotly()
text:
3.3 Creating an interactive scatter plot: ggplotly()

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
            aes(x = MATHS,
                y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))
ggplotly(p)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
3.4 Coordinated Multiple Views with plotly

highlight_key() of plotly package is used as shared data.
Two scatterplots will be created by using ggplot2 functions.
Lastly, subplot() of plotly package is used to place them next to each other side-by-side.



Code
d <- highlight_key(exam_data)
p1 <- ggplot(data=d, 
            aes(x = MATHS,
                y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

p2 <- ggplot(data=d, 
            aes(x = MATHS,
                y = SCIENCE)) +
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))
subplot(ggplotly(p1),
        ggplotly(p2))

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
4.1 Interactive Data Table: DT package

DT::datatable(exam_data, class= "compact")

title: Hands-on Exercise 3: Programming Interactive Data Visualisation with R
text:
4.2 Linked brushing: crosstalk


Code
d <- highlight_key(exam_data) 
p <- ggplot(d, 
            aes(ENGLISH, 
                MATHS)) + 
  geom_point(size=1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

gg <- highlight(ggplotly(p),        
                "plotly_selected")  

crosstalk::bscols(gg,               
                  DT::datatable(d), 
                  widths = 5)      






















Note




highlight() is a function of plotly package. It sets a variety of options for brushing (i.e., highlighting) multiple plots. These options are primarily designed for linking multiple plotly graphs, and may not behave as expected when linking plotly to another htmlwidget package via crosstalk. In some cases, other htmlwidgets will respect these options, such as persistent selection in leaflet.
bscols() is a helper function of crosstalk package. It makes it easy to put HTML elements side by side. It can be called directly from the console but is especially designed to work in an R Markdown document. Warning: This will bring in all of Bootstrap!.
